items.title: Homeownership has never seemed so out of reach. Will Trump’s Davos speech offer new hope?
items.summary: More details on plans to address housing affordability are expected in a speech Trump is scheduled to deliver in Davos on Wednesday.
items.author: Aarthi Swaminathan

items.title: Trade war redux? Greenland dispute threatens $1 trillion in trade between U.S. and Europe.
items.summary: President Donald Trump’s threat to pile new tariffs on some European countries resisting his effort to obtain Greenland have put trade fights back on the front burner and rattled global financial markets.
items.author: Jeffry Bartash

items.title: ‘People are often unreasonable when money is involved’: My husband, 62, gave me a 5-year life estate. Would I have to pay for a new roof?
items.summary: “He has included a provision stating that I would be responsible for ‘maintenance and expenses’ during my occupancy.”
items.author: Quentin Fottrell

items.title: ‘I’m simply exhausted’: I’m 55 and have $1.3 million for retirement. Can I retire next year?
items.summary: “I had a major health scare 4 years ago, and I’ve seen close friends die from cancer, heart disease, etc., way too soon.”
items.author: Quentin Fottrell

items.title: Trump’s Greenland tariff threats rattle investors: The stakes are higher this time around
items.summary: Retail investors don’t welcome the prospect of a prolonged trade war, but don’t freak out when you check your 401(k).
items.author: Quentin Fottrell

items.title: Gold and silver hit fresh records as Trump’s attack on ‘the existing world order’ stokes new surge in metal markets
items.summary: Investors are finding few other places to safeguard their portfolios after President Donald Trump threatened new tariffs on European allies.
items.author: Myra P. Saefong

items.title: The ‘Sell America’ trade is making a comeback on Tuesday. Here’s what investors need to know.
items.summary: The “Sell America” trade was making a comeback on Tuesday following President Donald Trump’s latest tariff threats against European allies, raising the possibility of a rerun of last April’s violent market spasms.
items.author: Joseph Adinolfi

items.title: Trump’s Greenland threats are making it even more expensive to buy a house in America
items.summary: Mortgage rates jumped higher as the Treasury market faces a selloff amid U.S.-E.U. tensions over Greenland.
items.author: Aarthi Swaminathan

items.title: AST SpaceMobile’s stock is on a roll. This key factor could make or break its momentum.
items.summary: The company needs to launch dozens of satellites this year to compete with its biggest rival, Starlink.
items.author: William Gavin

items.title: Intel’s stock pops as it finds a growing chorus on Wall Street
items.summary: Intel’s manufacturing business looks competitive, “or at least viable,” for the first time in a decade, according to a new bull.
items.author: Britney Nguyen

items.title: ‘I’m considering driving Lyft part time’: I’m 58 with a $1 million home. Do I finally give up work and enjoy life?
items.summary: “One thought is for me to stop working at age 60, while my wife continues for two more years at her teaching job.”
items.author: Quentin Fottrell

items.title: ‘It all feels impossible’: I’m 57 and on disability. My boyfriend died of a heart attack. Do I buy a townhouse or a condo?
items.summary: “I can afford a $175,000 cash purchase.”
items.author: Quentin Fottrell

items.title: Why oil experts say U.S.-Iran tensions feel different this time compared with previous crises
items.summary: Oil experts are factoring in the possibility of revolutionary upheaval in Iran as tensions with the U.S. flare back up.
items.author: Myra P. Saefong

items.title: Verizon’s outage may have annoyed users, but it didn’t bother investors
items.summary: Verizon’s stock rose Wednesday, despite reports of widespread outages of the company’s wireless service.
items.author: Bill Peters

items.title: Your wealth and investments are on the line if Trump torpedoes the Fed’s independence
items.summary: When politicians get involved with central-bank decisions, inflation, the dollar and the stock market all become less predictable.
items.author: Felix Vezina-Poirier

items.title: 3 ways to invest in what could become a $200 billion market for humanoid robots
items.summary: Analysts see investment opportunities in makers of components, defense technology and critical minerals that will be vital to the future of robotics.
items.author: William Gavin

items.title: Microsoft’s stock may be an AI winner — but it’s not acting like one
items.summary: Morgan Stanley says the stock looks “well underpriced” in part due to heavy corporate enthusiasm for the company’s AI offerings.
items.author: Emily Bary

items.title: Businesses across the U.S. are beginning to pass tariff costs to consumers, Fed’s ‘beige book’ finds
items.summary: Only two of a dozen Fed districts reported slight price growth. The rest saw higher costs.
items.author: Greg Robb

items.title: Saks files for bankruptcy. These big fashion brands — and tech names — are waiting to get paid.
items.summary: The Chapter 11 filing announced on Wednesday for the iconic, century-plus-old retailer — which oversees Saks Fifth Avenue, Neiman Marcus, Bergdorf Goodman and Saks Off 5th — could ripple through to other parts of the industry
items.author: Bill Peters

items.title: The financial elite aren’t worried about a stock-market bubble yet — but you can’t afford to be so complacent
items.summary: Investors know bull markets end, of course. But even the global leaders descending on Davos may underestimate the dangers.
items.author: Mark Hulbert
